@robertwb can you merge this please?

What a mess. Thanks for tackling this, and for linking to relevant context. If I understand correctly: 
1. `package-info.java` files generate spurious rebuilds because they don't by default generate a `.class` file which can be used to track necessary rebuild.
2. Adding a package annotation in the file causes it to generate a `.class` file.
3. The only standard annotation in JDK 1.5 is `@Deprecated`, so instead this defines a `@Package` annotation.

Did I grok that correctly? Makes sense to me. 

[One comment](https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/MCOMPILER-205?focusedCommentId=14428953&page=com.atlassian.jira.plugin.system.issuetabpanels:comment-tabpanel#comment-14428953) recommends `<exclude>`'ing the problematic files from incremental analysis. Have you tried that? This would presumably only be a problem if you made local changes to a `package-info.java` file which were important for rebuild. Since ours are all boilerplate, this shouldn't be an issue.

re: Is this ok for `build-tools`: I imagine `build-tools` for build resources rather than code dependencies, but that doesn't need be the case. This `@Package` annotation is specifically for influencing the build process, so in that context `build-tools` is the right place.

Isn't this a problem for all java modules and not just sdks/java/core?

The reason why I don't like this annotation based approach is that it requires all package info files to contain it to prevent this problem and is to workaround a limitation in the maven compiler plugin. Which is why I would prefer if we configured the maven compiler plugin in the root pom.xml to use -Xpkginfo:always or have a configuration with an exclusion line which filters out **/package-info.java?

4 out of 5 travis passed
should be ready to merge
Any reason to use a random ID rather than unique sequential IDs, i.e. from a static `AtomicLong`? Using random values risks spurious collisions (albeit improbable).
LGTM

@swegner yes, you got it. With the one missing piece that `-Xpkginfo:always` was added in Java 7 to have `javac` create the class files even if they have no content, but in fact this _always_ throws a NPE in all Java 7 JDKs we use :-). I previously proposed a PR with `<exclude>` but @davorbonaci didn't like that. I do think that changes to the javadoc might get missed? Surely a release build always starts with a `mvn clean` but just to be safe, I do agree with him that it is nice to not exclude them. I'm happy either way.

@lukecwik it could be, but the SDK is the one that I noticed having the rebuilds, while other modules did not (it has been a while since I bothered watching builds vs going and having a coffee - maybe this will get us closer to interactive speed). I didn't look into the status of other modules. I know our javadoc and/or checkstyle config now insists on having them. I'm willing to tag the rest here, but I prefer to quickly merge anything that is an improvement on status quo.
LGTM

I'm not a big fan of adding something which most people will not know about or check for making it easy to break what this change is attempting to do. The break will be a silent failure as well since things will still compile.

Good to know about -Xpkginfo not working. Any idea about just using the exclusion on **/package-info.java?

Apparently the JDK bug is only triggered when there is _also_ actual Java code. That might explain why it snuck past their testing.

Now this is split into two executions, so the `package-info.java` compilation can use `-Xpkginfo:always`. This is, I believe, a nearly ideal solution. I have confirm that merging #1204 and #1205 into master suppressed spurious rebuilds.

Travis failures are Eclipse issues and Travis infra failure, respectively. There was a non-crashing execution on Java 7, which is the important thing for the tests as far as this PR goes. Jenkins adds no coverage, since it is on a newer Java.

Okay, I spent a few hours on this, plus @davorbonaci helped :).

A few summaries:

### Regression: not threadsafe as proposed

The current PR's lazy getters are not threadsafe. Making them threadsafe requires some work, see link below.
- I am generally unhappy with putting any synchronized code on the encode()/decode() paths, because those are performance-critical. However, we hope is that a single volatile check will not be too bad.
- So if the perf impact is fairly negligible, well, it's probably fine to go ahead. If there is large perf impact, I'd vote for just registering Kryo to use Java serialization for this class. (And, if necessary, rewriting the serialization code in a better way to not need to expose the inner proxy class.)
  (The AvroCoder serialization was already convoluted crap, this is new crap, no change in amount of crap. ;).

You can assess the performance impact using the Avro microbenchmark:  https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/sdks/java/microbenchmarks/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/microbenchmarks/coders/AvroCoderBenchmark.java

Link: http://jeremymanson.blogspot.com/2008/05/double-checked-locking.html

### Does threadsafe matter?

Suppose the `volatile` variable access on the hotpath affects perf significantly. Do we care if we just use double-checked locking with no threadsafety?

Maybe not. So we create the ThreadLocals a bunch of times, if the instance is short-lived this may not matter much, and if the coder instance is long lived then eventually it will go across enough synchronization barriers that one will win. We will use extra memory, but since nothing is static we should eventually recover.

-Dan

R: @kennknowles 
CC: @jkff who noticed this

After chatting with @lukecwik, we decided that it was confusing to have a `.nested(..)` operation which does two things (effectively `.add(key, comp.getClass()).include(key, comp)`). We thought it would be surprising to have an automatically-added class item. Furthermore, the display data API today is purely additive, and it was confusing having configuration that could configure and subtract in the same fluent API (`.nested(..).withLabel(..).withoutClassItem()`).

We concluded that the current API is preferable because it is easier to understand and use, albeit being more syntax.

LGTM!

Speaking for the Flink runner/Flink: we have a very similar internal timer system but the API is a bit different. Essentially, what you call is `getInternalTimerService(String, TypeSerializer<N>)` which will get you an `InternalTimerService` for the given name/ID and that can store additional data (namespace) of type `N`. On this service you can register/delete processing-time and event-time timers. You can have several timers for each ID and deletion always requires giving the timestamp and namespace. 

So this is different from your changes where there is always only one timer per ID, setting a new timer deletes the old timer and deleting a timer doesn't require the exact timestamp/namespace, just the ID. To the user, we don't expose the ability to delete timers, right now, because it is a potentially costly operation that we might in the feature want to also get rid of internally. 

I think the updated interface of this PR can be used with the Flink timer service but it will require keeping additional state to allow deletion by ID. (I think, for now, not 100% sure.) I'm just mentioning this FYI, I still think the changes in this PR are good.

There is a conflict with a property in ApexPipelineOptions:

```
Caused by: java.lang.IllegalArgumentException: methods with same signature getParallelism() but incompatible return types: int and others
    at sun.misc.ProxyGenerator.checkReturnTypes(ProxyGenerator.java:656)
    at sun.misc.ProxyGenerator.generateClassFile(ProxyGenerator.java:461)
    at sun.misc.ProxyGenerator.generateProxyClass(ProxyGenerator.java:339)
    at java.lang.reflect.Proxy$ProxyClassFactory.apply(Proxy.java:639)
    at java.lang.reflect.Proxy$ProxyClassFactory.apply(Proxy.java:557)
    at java.lang.reflect.WeakCache$Factory.get(WeakCache.java:230)
    at java.lang.reflect.WeakCache.get(WeakCache.java:127)
    at java.lang.reflect.Proxy.getProxyClass0(Proxy.java:419)
    at java.lang.reflect.Proxy.getProxyClass(Proxy.java:371)
    at org.apache.beam.sdk.options.PipelineOptionsFactory.validateWellFormed(PipelineOptionsFactory.java:623)
    at org.apache.beam.sdk.options.PipelineOptionsFactory.register(PipelineOptionsFactory.java:561)
    at org.apache.beam.sdk.options.PipelineOptionsFactory.initializeRegistry(PipelineOptionsFactory.java:587)
    at org.apache.beam.sdk.options.PipelineOptionsFactory.<clinit>(PipelineOptionsFactory.java:536)
    ... 37 more
```

 Not sure why this comes up here only. I have commented out the property temporarily.
The other declaration is in `FlinkPipelineOptions` and they have to match exactly. I think switching `int` to `Integer` should fix it. The defaults might need to match too, I cannot remember.
This error message is poor. I think it is worth a JIRA to improve it and catch the error in our own validation, not the ProxyGenerator.

The tests pass in the last iteration, squashed the commits. I need to work on how to determine from the source that there is no more input so the runner can terminate (vs. sitting idle till timeout). Here the source is `TextIO.Read.from(options.getInputFile())`. When the source is bounded and advance returns false, can the pipeline shutdown. Currently that's only done for ValuesSource:

https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/apex-runner/runners/apex/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/apex/translators/io/ApexReadUnboundedInputOperator.java#L77
@kennknowles PR ready or review.

retest this please

Based on all this, I'd consider dropping timer deletion. It is used currently only for clearing EOW/GC timers for obsolete merging windows (but if those timers get delivered it is fine, just a storage/management thing). But as you say, it can be implemented perhaps using state and is probably helpful for end users usability. If we don't have `deleteTimer` it will be a question people always ask "why?" :-)

For now I'll merge since everyone seems OK as-is, and the naming difference will go away as I do think we can delete the no-ID version of everything before we go stable.

Once `advance` returns false, you actually _must_ close it: https://github.com/apache/incubator-beam/blob/master/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/BoundedSource.java#L89

For unbounded data, when the watermark reaches infinity (`BoundedWindow.TIMESTAMP_MAX_VALUE`) then you can/should shut it down. Only some runners manage to do this.
